Local hospitals and clinics, even in areas considered under rebel control, were reporting hundreds of cases of gunshot wounds and the death toll was impossible to estimate.{{cite news|last=Kirkpatrick|first=David D.|title=Qaddafi Defiant After Rebel Takeover|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/24/world/africa/24libya.html?_r=1&hp|accessdate=24 August 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=23 August 2011}} By late afternoon the journalists trapped at the Rixos Hotel had been released while heavy fighting continued in the Abu Salim region close to Bab al-Azizia and elsewhere.{{cite news|title=Rebels Hunt Qaddafi; Journalists in Hotel Are Free|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/25/world/africa/25libya.html?_r=1&hp|accessdate=24 August 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=25 August 2011|first1=Kareem|last1=Fahim|first2=Rick|last2=Gladstone}} The rebels were reported as estimating 400 people had been killed and a further 2,000 injured in the battle thus far.{{cite news|title=Street fighting rages in Tripoli as Gaddafi loyalists fight rearguard action|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/aug/24/fighting-tripoli-gaddafi-libya|accessdate=25 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=25 August 2011|first1=Martin|last1=Chulov|first2=Luke|last2=Harding|first3=Julian|last3=Borger|location=London}} ===After Tripoli and NTC victory=== {{see also|Death of Muammar Gaddafi}} Efforts to mop up pro-Gaddafi forces in northwestern Libya and toward [[Sirte]] began even before the rebels fully consolidated control of Tripoli. Rebels took the city of [[Ghadames]] near the borders of Tunisia and Algeria on 29 August. Members of the Gaddafi family have taken flight to Algeria. In September, the Gaddafi stronghold of Bani Walid was besieged by rebels, who reported that Gaddafi's son Saif al-Islam was hiding in the city.{{cite news|author=Ian Black in Tripoli and Chris Stephen in Misrata |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/sep/19/gaddafi-son-spotted-bani-walid |title=Libya: Gaddafi son spotted in Bani Walid as heavy fighting continues|publisher=The Guardian |date= 19 September 2011|accessdate=2011-10-28}} On 22 September, the NTC captured the southern city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]], and claimed to have found a large cache of [[chemical weapons]].{{cite news|author=Ian Black in Tripoli |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/sep/22/libyan-rebels-gaddafis-chemical-weapons |title=Libyan rebels discover Gaddafi's chemical weapons|publisher=Guardian |date= 22 September 2011|accessdate=2011-10-28}} Concerns were raised over the danger of Gaddafi mounting an insurgency against the new authorities.[http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/10/05/idINIndia-59724420111005 Gaddafi determined to avoid Saddam Hussein's fate], Reuters, 5 October 2011 By mid-October 2011, much of the city of [[Sirte]] had been taken by NTC forces, although [[Battle of Sirte (2011)|fierce fighting continued around the city center]], where many pro-Gaddafi fighters were encamped.http://www.channel4.com/news/ferocious-fighting-in-sirte-as-ntc-tightens-grip [[Channel 4 News]]. Retrieved 2011-10-08. The NTC captured the whole of Sirte on 20 October 2011, and reported that Gaddafi himself had been killed in the city.[http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE79J09O20111020 "Libya forces capture Sirte"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 2011-10-20.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15389550 "Muammar Gaddafi killed in Libya"]. BBC. Retrieved 2011-10-20. Some civilian Gaddafi supporters remaining in the city reported that women and children had been killed in crossfire or fired upon by rebel forces. There were also reports of harassment and theft by rebels, however the rebel army indicated it would leave unarmed civilians "to their own devices", and had allowed families in the city access to supplies and medical assistance.{{cite news|last=Sherlock|first=Ruth|title=Gaddafi loyalists stranded as battle for Sirte rages|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8802302/Gaddafi-loyalists-stranded-as-battle-for-Sirte-rages.html|accessdate=28 October 2011|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2 October 2011}} ===Aftermath=== {{main|Aftermath of the 2011 Libyan civil war}} Despite the defeat of Gaddafi's loyalists, capture of last loyalist cities and Gaddafi's death, Saif al-Islam, Gaddafi's son and successor, remained hiding in the southern region of Libya until his capture in mid-November. In addition, some loyalist forces crossed into Niger, though the escape attempts exploded into violence, when detected by Niger troops. Sporadic clashes between NTC and former loyalists also continued across Libya with low intensity. On November 23, seven people were killed in clashes at Bani Walid, five of them among the revolutionary forces and one Gaddafi loyalist.http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/23/178863.html ==Humanitarian situation== {{main|Humanitarian situation during the 2011 Libyan civil war}} By the end of February 2011, supplies of medicine, fuel and food were dangerously low in Libya's urban centres.{{cite web | author=Staff | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/20112289513477110.html | title=Libya's Humanitarian Crisis â As Protests Continue, Medical Supplies, Along with Fuel and Food, Are Running Dangerously Short | date=28 February 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera English }} On 25 February, the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] launched an emergency appeal for {{Currency|6.4 million|US}} to meet the emergency needs of people affected by the violent unrest in Libya.{{Cite news | author=Press release | title=Libya: ICRC Launches Emergency Appeal as Humanitarian Situation Deteriorates | publisher=[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] | date=25 February 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011 | url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/news-release/2011/libya-news-2011-02-25.htm }} In early March, the fighting across Libya meant that more than a million people fleeing or inside the country needed humanitarian aid.{{cite news |author=Staff|title=UN Says To Deliver First Food Aid in Libya Tuesday |url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7271FC20110308 |agency=Reuters |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=13 March 2011}}{{cite news | author=Press release | title= WFP Trucks Food into Eastern Libya |url=http://reliefweb.int/node/391021 |publisher=[[World Food Programme]] (via [[ReliefWeb]]) |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=12 September 2011}} The [[Islamic Relief]] and the WFP also coordinated a shipment of humanitarian supplies to Misrata.Staff. [http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Full_Report_152.pdf ''OCHA on Libya's Refugees Covering the Period of 10 to 12 April''] ([[Portable Document Format|PDF]]; requires [[Adobe Acrobat|Adobe Reader]]). [[Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs|UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]] (via [[ReliefWeb]]). Retrieved 18 April 2011 In March, the [[Government of Sweden|Swedish government]] donated medical supplies and other humanitarian aid and the UN [[World Food Programme]] provided food. Turkey sent a hospital ship to Misrata and a Turkish cargo ship brought 141 tons of humanitarian aid.{{cite web|url=http://www.ihh.org.tr/ihh-dan-libya-ya-insani-yardim-gemisi/en/ |title=IHH Sends Humanitarian Aid Ship to Libya |publisher=[[IHH (Turkish NGO)|IHH Humanitarian Relief Foundation]]|date=28 March 2011 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} Another humanitarian issue was refugees fleeing the crisis. A humanitarian ship docked in harbour of Misrata in April to begin the evacuation of stranded migrants.{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE73E0W220110415?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title=Rockets Bombard Misrata, Rebels Say Eight Killed |agency=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=16 April 2011}} By 10 July, over 150,000 migrants were evacutated.{{cite web|title=Migration crisis from Libya|url=http://migration-crisis.com/libya/|publisher=International Organization for Migration|accessdate=12 September 2011}} Migrants were also stranded elsewhere in Libya, such as in the southern towns of Sebha and Gatroum. Fleeing the violence of Tripoli by road, as many as 4,000 refugees were crossing the LibyaâTunisia border daily during the first days of the uprising. Among those escaping the violence were native Libyans as well as foreign nationals including Egyptians, Tunisians and Turks.{{Cite news|author=Staff|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/africa-mideast/live-update-thousands-flee-across-libya-tunisia-border/article1918670/ |title=Live Update: Thousands Flee Across LibyaâTunisia Border |work=Globe and Mail |location=Canada |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |location=Toronto}} ===Potential militaryâhumanitarian coordination=== While the UN sanctioned military intervention has been implemented on humanitarian grounds, UN agencies seeking to ease the humanitarian crisis repeatedly rejected offers of support from the military to carry out the agencies' humanitarian operations.Metcalfe, Victoria (2011). [http://www.odi.org.uk/resources/details.asp?id=5747&title=friend-foe-military-intervention-in-libya "Friend or Foe? Military Intervention in Libya"]. [[Overseas Development Institute]]. The conditions under which such support may be accepted are outlined in the Guidelines on the Use of Military and Civil Defence Assets to Support United Nations Humanitarian Activities in Complex Emergencies (MCDA), whereby military support can be used but only temporarily and as a last resort. Yet, there remains the concern that aid agencies' neutrality will be brought into question by accepting military support, putting aid staff at risk of being [[Attacks on humanitarian workers|attacked]] and causing some parties to prevent the agencies accessing all the areas they need to. Furthermore, the military may not always have the technical skills required to assess the need for aid and to ensure its effective distribution. Despite this, offers continue for the creation of an aid corridor and aid agencies have accepted military logistical support in the past, for instance in the [[2010 Pakistan floods]] response. ===Targeting of black Libyans and sub-Saharan Africans=== In August 2011, the [[UNHCR]] issued a strong call for the rights and lives of [[sub-Saharan Africa]]ns living in Libya to be protected due to reports that black Africans were being targeted by the rebel forces as cities fell.{{cite web |url=http://www.unhcr.org/4e57d1cb9.html| title=UNHCR reports on blacks being targetted}} Other news sources including ''[[The Independent]]'' and [[CNN]] have reported on the targeting of [[black people]] in rebel held areas.{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/rebels-settle-scores-in-libyan-capital-2344671.html| title=Independent reports on blacks being targeted |location=London |work=The Independent | first=Kim | last=Sengupta | date=27 August 2011}} and {{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/world/2011/08/31/robertson.libya.african.jails.cnn?&hpt=hp_c2|title=CNN reports on blacks being targeted}} and {{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/08/30/140052803/liyban-rebels-wary-of-sub-saharan-africans|title=NPR reports on blacks being targeted}} An [[Amnesty International]] statement, released on 30 August 2011, stated that on visits to detention centres in [[Zawiya, Libya|Zawiya]] and [[Tripoli]], Amnesty International was informed that between one third and half of those detained were from Sub-Saharan Africa. A New York Times online article also comments that "it seems that plenty of the black Africans captured as mercenaries were never actually involved in the fight".{{cite web|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libya-fears-detainees-held-forces-loyal-ntc-2011-08-30|title=Amnesty International reports on blacks being targeted}} and {{cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/01/blacks-in-libya-face-danger-from-rebels/|title=New York Times report on many Black Africans captured were not mercenaries | work=The New York Times|first=Elizabeth A.|last=Harris|date=1 September 2011}} and {{cite web|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libya-fears-detainees-held-forces-loyal-ntc-2011-08-30|title=Amnesty reports round up of Black Africans}} "Hundreds of thousands of sub-Saharan Africans worked in Gaddafi's Libya, doing everything from managing hotels to sweeping floors. But some also fought as pro-Gaddafi mercenaries, and many migrant workers [-] fled ahead of the rebels, fearing they would be mistaken for mercenaries."Elders hold talks over Gaddafi's stronghold, ''The Independent'', 6 September 2011.[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/elders-hold-talks-over-gaddafi-stronghold-2349971.html] The ''[[Miami Herald]]'' reported that some African women have claimed rebels are raping them in [[refugee camp]]s, with additional reports of forced labour. Foreign aid workers are also claiming to be prohibited from officially talking about the allegations.{{cite web|url= http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/09/07/v-fullstory/2395392/african-women-say-rebels-raped.html|title=Miami Herald reports on rebels raping Africans}} The town of [[Taworgha]], which supported Gaddafi prior to its [[Battle of Taworgha|capture]] by anti-Gaddafi fighters in August, has been emptied of its mostly black inhabitants in what appeared to be a "major reprisal against supporters of the Gaddafi regime", according to an 11 September report from ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'', and commanders of the [[Misrata Brigade]] are refusing to allow the displaced townspeople to return. One commander was quoted as saying, "Taworgha no longer exists."{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8754375/Gaddafis-ghost-town-after-the-loyalists-retreat.html|agency=The Telegraph|first=Andrew|last=Gilligan|date=11 September 2011|accessdate=12 September 2011|title=Gaddafi's ghost town after the loyalists retreat|work=The Daily Telegraph}} ==Libyan refugees== {{main|Refugees of the 2011 Libyan civil war}} Fleeing the violence of Tripoli by road, as many as 4,000 refugees were crossing the Libya–Tunisia border daily during the first days of the uprising. Among those, escaping the violence, were native Libyans as well as foreign nationals including Egyptians, Tunisians and Turks.{{Cite news|author=Staff|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/africa-mideast/live-update-thousands-flee-across-libya-tunisia-border/article1918670/ |title=Live Update: Thousands Flee Across LibyaâTunisia Border |work= [[The Globe and Mail]] |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}} In February, Italian Foreign Minister Frattini expressed his concerns that the amount of Libyan refugees trying to reach Italy might reach between 200,000 and 300,000 people.{{cite news| author =Squires, Nick |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8343963/Libya-Italy-fears-300000-refugees.html |title=Libya: Italy Fears 300,000 Refugees |work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=23 February 2011 |accessdate= 7 July 2011}} By 1 March, officials from the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|UN High Commissioner for Refugees]] had confirmed allegations of discrimination against sub-Saharan Africans who were held in dangerous conditions in the no-man's-land between Tunisia and Libya.{{Cite news|url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/africa-mideast/at-a-tense-border-crossing-a-systematic-effort-to-keep-black-africans-out/article1925955/|title = At a Tense Border Crossing, a Systematic Effort To Keep Black Africans Out|author=Saunders, Doug |date=1 March 2011 |work= [[The Globe and Mail]] |accessdate=3 March 2011 }} By 3 March, an estimated 200,000 refugees had fled Libya to either Tunisia or Egypt. A provisional refugee camp set up at [[Ras Ejder]] with a capacity for 10,000 was overflowing with an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 refugees. Many tens of thousands were still trapped on the Libyan side of the frontier. By 3 March, the situation was described as a logistical nightmare, with the [[World Health Organization]] warning of the risk of epidemics.Sayar, Scott; [[Alan Cowell|Cowell, Alan]] (3 March 2011). [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/04/world/africa/04refugee.html Libyan Refugee Crisis Called a 'Logistical Nightmare'"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. To continue responding to the needs of people staying at the [[Ras Ejder]] crossing point in Tunisia, the WFP and [[Secours Islamique-France]] were upgrading a kitchen that would provide breakfast for families. Separately, the ICRC advised it was handing over its operations at the Choucha Camp to the [[Tunisian Red Crescent]].{{cite news|url=http://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/update/2011/libya-update-2011-04-15.htm |title=Libya: More Aid To Reach Misrata and Other Areas |publisher= [[International Committee of the Red Cross]] |accessdate=18 April 2011}} Since 24 March, the WFP supplied over 42,500 cooked meals for TCNs at the Saloum border. A total of 1,650 cartons of fortified date bars (equivalent of 13.2 metric tons) had also been provided to supplement these meals. ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]'' reported on 11 September that almost the entire population of [[Taworgha]], a town of about 10,000 people, had been forced to flee their homes by anti-Gaddafi fighters after their [[Battle of Taworgha|takeover of the settlement]]. The report suggested that Taworgha, which was dominated by [[black people|black]] Libyans, may have been the subject of [[ethnic cleansing]] provoked by a combination of [[racism]] and bitterness on the part of [[Misrata]]n fighters over the town's support for Gaddafi during the [[Battle of Misrata|siege of Misrata]]. ==Casualties== {{Main|Casualties of the 2011 Libyan civil war}} [[File:Protest In Dublin Gaddafi Is A Murderer.jpg|thumb|People in [[Dublin]], Ireland, protesting against [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s use of violence against Libyans (19 March 2011).]] Independent numbers of dead and injured in the conflict have still not been made available. Estimates have been widely varied. On 24 February 2011, the [[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]] reported that the [[International Criminal Court]] estimated 10,000 had been killed.{{cite web |author=Staff|date=24 February 2011| url=http://english.irib.ir/news/political/item/71535-death-toll-in-libyan-popular-uprising-at-10000|title=Death Toll in Libyan Popular Uprising at 10,000|publisher=[[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]]|accessdate=5 August 2011}} The numbers of injured were estimated to be around 4,000 by 22 February. On 2 March, the [[World Health Organization]] estimated approximately 2,000 killed.{{cite web |author=Staff|date=2 March 2011| url=http://rt.com/news/line/2011-03-02/|title= RT News Line, March 2|publisher=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=5 August 2011}} At the same time, the opposition claimed that 6,500 people had died.{{Cite news|author=Staff|url=http://www.sify.com/news/at-least-3-000-dead-in-libya-rights-group-news-international-ldcxkhgggdh.html|title=At Least 3,000 Dead in Libya: Rights Group|publisher=[[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] (via [[Sify News]]) |date=2 March 2011|accessdate=5 August 2011}} Later, rebel spokesman [[Abdul Hafiz Ghoga]] reported that the death toll reached 8,000. In June 2011, [[Amnesty International]] stated that earlier estimates of the initial clashes in February were exaggerated. It estimated that during the first few days of the conflict, 100 to 110 people were killed in Benghazi and 59 to 64 were killed in [[Bayda, Libya|Baida]]. On 8 September, Naji Barakat, the Health Minister of the [[National Transitional Council]], stated that about half of an estimated 30,000 dead were believed to have been pro-Gaddafi fighters. War wounded were estimated as at least 50,000, of which about 20,000 were serious injuries, but this estimate was expected to rise.{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/feedarticle/9835879 |title=Libyan estimate: At least 30,000 died in the war |author=Karin Laub |agency=Associated Press |work=The Guardian |date=8 September 2011 |accessdate=25 November 2011}} However, there was no independent verification of the Health Minister's claim and, one month later, the NTC reduced the estimated number of killed to 25,000. ==Domestic responses== {{Main|Domestic responses to the 2011 Libyan civil war}} ===Resignation of government officials=== In response to the use of force against protesters, a number of senior Libyan public officials either renounced the Gaddafi government or [[Domestic responses to the 2011 Libyan civil war|resigned from their positions]]. Justice Minister [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]] and Interior Minister Major General [[Abdul Fatah Younis]] both defected to the opposition. Oil Minister [[Shukri Ghanem]] and Foreign Minister [[Moussa Koussa]] fled Libya, with the latter defecting to the UK.{{cite web | author=Press release | url = http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=576566082|title = Foreign Office Statement on Musa Kusa|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office]]|date=30 March 2011|accessdate=30 March 2011}} Libyan Prosecutor General [[Abdul-Rahman al-Abbar]] resigned his position and joined the opposition.{{cite news |author=Abdelatti, Ail; Werr, Patrick|title=Libya's Prosecutor General Says Joins Opposition|agency=Reuters |date=25 February 2011|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/25/libya-prosecutor-idUSWEB186120110225|accessdate=26 February 2011}} The staff of a number of diplomatic missions of Libya have either resigned or condemned the actions of the Gaddafi government. The ambassadors to the [[Arab League]], European Union and United Nations have either resigned or stated that they no longer support the government.{{Cite news|author=Staff|title = Libya's Ambassadors Retrieved 27 March 2011. ===Economic, religious and tribal=== The Libyan economy is mainly based on [[Oil reserves in Libya|its oil production]]. The [[Arabian Gulf Oil Company]], the second-largest state-owned oil company in Libya, announced plans to use oil funds to support anti-Gaddafi forces.Staff (11 March 2011). [http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL3E7EB03B20110311 "Libya's Arabian Gulf Oil Co Hopes To Fund Rebels Via Crude Sales-FT"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 18 March 2011. Islamic leaders and clerics in Libya, notably the [[Network of Free Ulema â Libya]] urged all Muslims to rebel against Gaddafi.{{cite web |author=Staff|url= http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/17/live-blog-libya |title=Live Blog â Libya|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=17 March 2011}}{{cite news|author=Staff|url= http://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFLDE71K1TQ20110221 |title=Update 1-Libyan Islamic Leaders Urge Muslims To Rebel|agency=Reuters |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}} The [[Warfalla]], [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] and [[Magarha]] tribes announced their support of the protesters.{{Cite news |author=Staff|title = Gaddafi Defiant as State Teeters â Libyan Leader Vows To 'Fight On' as His Government Loses Control of Key Parts in the Country and as Top Officials Quit|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=23 February 2011 |url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112235434767487.html |accessdate=19 March 2011}} The [[Zuwayya]] tribe, based in eastern Libya, threatened to cut off oil exports from fields in its part of Libya if Libyan security forces continued attacking demonstrators.{{Cite news|author=Hussein, Mohammed|url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12528996|title = Libya Crisis: What Role Do Tribal Loyalties Play?|publisher=BBC News |date=21 February 2011|accessdate=18 March 2011}} ===Libyan royal family=== [[File:A Benghazi citizen holding King Idris's photo.JPG|thumb|A young Benghazian carrying (deposed) King Idris' photo. Support of the [[Senussi|Senussi dynasty]] has traditionally been strong in [[Cyrenaica]].{{Cite news|author=Staff|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18239900?story_id=18239900|title = Building a New Libya â Around Benghazi, Muammar Qaddafi's Enemies Have Triumphed|date=24 February 2011 |work=The Economist|accessdate=18 March 2011}}]] [[Muhammad as-Senussi]], son of the former Crown Prince and grand-nephew of the late King [[Idris of Libya|Idris]],{{cite web|url=http://www.royalark.net/Libya/libya6.htm |title=Royal Ark; Libya 6 |publisher=Royalark.net |accessdate=7 July 2011}} sent his condolences "for the heroes who have laid down their lives, killed by the brutal forces of Gaddafi" and called on the international community "to halt all support for the dictator with immediate effect."{{Cite news|author=Salama, Vivian|title = Libya's Crown Prince Says Protesters Will Defy 'Brutal Forces'| publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=22 February 2011|url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-22/libya-s-crown-prince-says-protesters-will-defy-brutal-forces-.html|accessdate=17 March 2011}} as-Senussi said that the protesters would be "victorious in the end" and calls for international support to end the violence. On 24 February, as-Senussi gave an interview to Al Jazeera where he called upon the international community to help remove Gaddafi from power and stop the ongoing "massacre".{{Cite news|author=Staff| title = Libya's 'Crown Prince' Makes Appeal â Muhammad al-Senussi Calls for the International Community To Help Remove Muammar Gaddafi from Power|publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=24 February 2011|url = http://english.aljazeera.net/video/africa/2011/02/201122416028655869.html |accessdate=17 March 2011}} He dismissed talk of a civil war saying "The Libyan people and the tribes have proven they are united". He later stated that international community needs "less talk and more action" to stop the violence.{{cite news|url= http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle09.asp?xfile=data/international/2011/March/international_March491.xml§ion=international|title=Libya's 'Exiled Prince' Urges World Action|author=Staff|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via ''[[Khaleej Times]]'')|date=9 March 2011|accessdate=17 March 2011}} He asked for a no-fly zone over Libya but does not support foreign Cynthia|agency=Reuters |date=9 March 2011|accessdate=17 March 2011}} On 20 April, Mohammed spoke in front of the [[European Parliament]] calling for more support for Libya.{{cite web |url= http://blogs.wsj.com/brussels/2011/04/20/libyan-prince-im-ready-to-be-king/ |title=Libyan Prince: I'm Ready To Be King |work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=23 April 2011 |author=Miller, John It was also reported attempts at contact had been initiated by French and Saudi officials.{{cite web|url = http://www.worldtribune.com/worldtribune/WTARC/2011/me_libya0317_03_21.asp|title = With NATO's Operation Odyssey Dawn Launch, Strategic Dimensions Come into Focus|author=Copley, Greg|work=[[World Tribune]]|date=21 March 2011|accessdate=22 March 2011}} On 3 March, it was reported that another member of the family, Prince Zouber al-Senussi, had fled Libya with his family and was seeking asylum in [[Totebo]], Sweden.{{cite web|url = http://www.stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=6842| title = Libyan Royal Family Seeking Swedish Asylum|author=Staff|work=[[Tidningarnas TelegrambyrÃ¥]] (via ''[[Stockholm News]]'')| date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=17 March 2011}} ==International reactions== {{main|International reactions to the 2011 Libyan civil war|US domestic reactions to the 2011 military intervention in Libya}} [[File:China Eastern Airbus A340 in Malta Zammit.jpg|thumb|A total of 19 charter flights evacuated Chinese citizens from Libya via [[Malta]].{{cite news|url=http://www.china.org.cn/world/2011-03/05/content_22065482.htm|title=Chinese evacuation from Libya via Malta ends|date=5 March 2011|publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|accessdate=16 September 2011}} Here a chartered [[China Eastern Airlines]] [[Airbus A340]] is seen at [[Malta International Airport]] on 26 February 2011.]] Many states and [[supranational]] bodies condemned Gaddafi's government over its attacks on civilian targets within the country. Virtually all Western countries cut off diplomatic relations with Gaddafi's government over an aerial bombing campaign in February and March, and a number of other countries led by [[Peru]] and [[Botswana]] did likewise. [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1970]] was adopted on 26 February, freezing the assets of Gaddafi and ten members of his inner circle and restricting their travel. The resolution also referred the actions of the government to the [[International Criminal Court]] for investigation, and an arrest warrant for Gaddafi was issued on 27 June.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13927208 |title=Libya: Muammar Gaddafi Subject to ICC Arrest Warrant |work=BBC News |date=27 June 2011|accessdate=14 August 2011}} This was followed by an arrest warrant issued by [[Interpol]] on 8 September.{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/09/us-libya-gaddafi-interpol-idUSTRE7882D220110909 |agency=Reuters |first=John | last=Irish | title=Interpol issues arrest warrant for Muammar Gaddafi | date=9 September 2011}} The government's use of the [[Libyan Air Force]] to strike civilians led to the adoption of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973]] to create a [[Libyan no-fly zone]] on 17 March, though several countries involved in the resolution's enforcement have also carried out regular strike missions to degrade the offensive capacity of the [[Libyan Army]] and destroy the government's [[command and control]] capabilities, effectively acting in ''de facto'' support of [[anti-Gaddafi forces]] on the ground. 100 countries have recognized the anti-Gaddafi [[National Transitional Council]] as Libya's legitimate representative, with many of those countries explicitly describing it as the legal interim government of the country due to the perceived loss of legitimacy on the part of Gaddafi's government. Many states have also either issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] or attempted evacuations. Some evacuations were successful in either going to [[Malta]] or via land borders to [[Egypt]] or [[Tunisia]]; other attempts were hindered by tarmac damage at [[Benghazi]]'s airport or refusals of permission to land in [[Tripoli]]. There were also several solidarity protests in other countries that were mostly composed of Libyan [[expatriates]]. Financial markets around the world had adverse reactions to the instability with oil prices rising to a two-and-a-half year high. {{see also|Foreign relations of the National Transitional Council}}
